title: 115_s1105
content: The Act may be cited as the "Miners Pension Protection Act" and includes transfers to the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include additional amounts for the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan if the dollar limitation exceeds the required transfer amount for a fiscal year. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include additional amounts for the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan if the funded percentage reaches 100 percent, with a prohibition on benefit increases during receiving transfers. The amendment allows for the rate at which benefits become nonforfeitable under the plan to be adjusted, with certain conditions required for qualification under the Internal Revenue Code. Transfers made under the amendment are disregarded in determining unfunded vested benefits and withdrawal liability under ERISA. The Miners Pension Protection Act of 1974 requires maintaining contribution rates for the UMWA Pension Plan. Enhanced annual reporting is mandated for the trustees of the plan to file with the Secretary of the Treasury. The Miners Pension Protection Act of 1974 mandates enhanced annual reporting for the UMWA Pension Plan trustees to file with the Secretary of the Treasury or the Secretary's delegate and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The report must include whether the plan is in endangered or critical status under specific sections of the law. The Miners Pension Protection Act of 1974 requires UMWA Pension Plan trustees to submit detailed annual reports to the Secretary of the Treasury or the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The report must include information on the plan's funded percentage, market value of assets, contributions made, and other key financial details. The annual report must include details such as benefits paid, cash flow projections for the upcoming years, funding standard account projections, and total asset value. The annual report must also include information on investment gains or losses, significant reduction in active participants, employers that withdrew from the plan, and employers that paid withdrawal liability. The annual report must include details on withdrawal liability payments made by employers, changes to benefits or contribution rates, and scheduled benefit adjustments. The annual report must include information on funding improvement and rehabilitation plans, participant numbers, and beneficiary details from the preceding plan year. The annual report must include information on funding improvement and rehabilitation plans, participant numbers, beneficiary details, annual funding notice, Department of Labor Form 5500, plan documents, amendments, and contribution obligations. The annual report must include participant census data, actuarial valuation report, collective bargaining agreements, financial reports, and other information as required by the Secretary of the Treasury, Secretary of Labor, and Director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The annual report required by the Corporation must be submitted electronically and shared with the Secretary of Labor. Failure to file the report on time will result in a penalty. The annual report for the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan must be filed electronically with the Secretary of Labor. Failure to file on time incurs a penalty of $100 instead of $25, unless reasonable diligence is proven by the plan trustees. The amendments to the UMWA Pension Plan apply to fiscal years starting after September 30, 2016, with reporting requirements for plan years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. CUSTOMS USER FEES. Amends the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act and the United States-Korea Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act by changing the deadline for certain provisions from January 14, 2026, to May 13, 2026.
